EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

Scout is committed to excellence in our operations. We will provide a safe and productive workplace for our employees, conduct our operations in an environmentally responsible manner, comply with applicable laws and regulations and improve the communities where we live and work. We recognize that operating excellence does not just happen, and that we need to have management tools in place to organize and sustain the effort. Achieving excellence in our operations is the responsibility of every employee.  Operations line management must ensure the development and implementation of procedures which guide employee actions as appropriate.



ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND RESPONSE POLICIES

The Dollarhide Gas Plant has a long-standing commitment to worker and public safety. This commitment is demonstrated by the resources invested in accident prevention, personnel training, engineering controls in the design, installation, operation, and maintenance of our process. Our policy is to implement reasonable controls to prevent accidental and uncontrolled releases of regulated substances. 



DESCRIPTION OF THE STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES

The Dollarhide Gas Plant is located in Andrews County, Texas 35 miles southwest of Andrews. The boundaries of the stationary source are defined by the external fence surrounding the facility. The plant's cryogenic unit processes a dry residue gas from accumulated casing head gas production to produce Natural Gas Liquids, or NGLs. Methane, Ethane, Propane, n-butane, i-butane, n-pentane and i-pentane are regulated flammable hydrocarbons contained in the NGLs. Also, the plant uses refrigerant grade propane for refrigeration purposes. The Dollarhide Gas Plant does not use and/or process any regulated toxic substances above threshold quantities.

                   

GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM

Dollarhide Gas Plant is a RMP Program 1 facility. Because the process at the Dollarhide Gas Plant that is r

egulated by the Environmental Protection Agency's (EPA's) Risk Management Program (RMP)regulation is also subject to the Occupational Safety and Health Administration's (OSHA's) Process Safety Management (PSM) standard, this summary addresses each of the OSHA PSM elements and describes the system in place to implement the Accidental Release Prevention Program: 



Employee Participation:

Management at the Dollarhide Gas Plant encourages employees to participate in all facets of process safety management and accident prevention. Examples of employee participation range from updating and compiling technical documents and chemical information to participating as a member of a process hazard analysis (PHA) team. Employees have access to all information created as part of the gas plant accident prevention program. Specific ways that employees can be involved in the accident prevention program are documented in an employee participation plan that is maintained in the Process Safety SharePoint of the facility and which addresses each accidental release prevention program element.



Process Safety Information (PSI):

The Dollarhide Gas Plant keeps a variety of technical documents that are used to help maintain safe operation of the process. These documents address chemical properties and associated hazards, chemical inventories, and equipment design basis/configuration information. Specific departments within Scout are assigned responsibility for maintaining up-to-date process safety information. An electronic library or system of records for the reference documents is readily available as part of the written employee participation plan to help employees locate any necessary process safety information.



Chemical specific information, including exposure hazards, emergency response, PPE requirements and exposure treatment considerations are provided in Safety Data Sheets (SDS) as part of the HAZCOM program. For specific process areas, the gas plant has documented safety-r

ated limits for specific process parameters (e.g., temperature, level, pressure) in the Operating Procedures of the facility. The gas plant ensures that the process is maintained within these limits using process controls and monitoring instruments, trained personnel, and protective instrument systems (e.g., automated shutdown systems).



The Dollarhide Gas Plant also maintains numerous technical documents that provide information about the design and construction of process equipment. This information includes materials of construction, design pressure and temperature ratings, and electrical rating of equipment. This information, in combination with written procedures and trained personnel, provides a basis for establishing inspection and maintenance activities, as well as for evaluating proposed process and facility changes to ensure that safety features in the process are not compromised.

 

Process Hazard Analysis (PHA):

The Dollarhide Gas Plant conducts process hazard analysis to help ensure that hazards associated with the process are identified and controlled. Within this studies, the process is systematically examined to identify hazards and ensure that adequate controls are in place to manage these hazards.



The Dolarhide Gas Plant uses the HazOpS and LOPA methodologies on these studies. The studies are conducted using a team of people that will be knowledgeable in the specific process hazard analysis methodology used. This team identifies and evaluates hazards of the process as well as accident prevention and mitigation measures, and the team makes suggestions for additional prevention and/or mitigation measures when the team believes such measures are necessary.



The PHA team findings are forwarded to local management for resolution. Implementation of mitigation options in response to PHA findings is based on a relative risk ranking assigned by the PHA team. This ranking helps ensure that potential accident scenarios assigned the highest risk recei

ve immediate attention. All approved mitigation options in response to PHA team findings are tracked until they are completed. The PHA team findings are shared with the affected personnel and the final resolution of each finding is documented and retained.



To help ensure that the process controls and/or process hazards do not eventually deviate significantly from the original design safety features, the plant periodically updates and revalidates the hazard analysis results. These periodic reviews are conducted at least every 5 years and will be conducted at this frequency until the process is no longer operating. The results and findings from these updates are documented and retained.



Operating Procedures:

The Dollarhide Gas Plant maintains written procedures that address various modes of process operations. These procedures are used as operating references by operations personnel and serve as training procedures for new operators. These procedures are periodically reviewed and annually certified as current and accurate. The procedures are kept current and accurate by revising them as necessary to reflect changes made through the MOC process. In addition, the Dollarhide Gas Plant maintains a Key Process Parameter in the DCS System that provides alarm notification for excess process control deviations. This information, along with written operating procedures is readily available to operators in the process unit and for other personnel to use as necessary to safely perform their job tasks.



In addition, the Dollarhide Gas Plant maintains Safe Operating Limits/Consequences of Deviation tables that provide guidance on how to respond to upper or lower limit exceedances for specific process or equipment parameters. This information, along with written operating procedures, is readily available to operators in the process unit and for other personnel to use as necessary to safely perform their job tasks.

 

Training:

Complemented by the written procedures the D

ollarhide Gas Plant personnel maintain job proficiency through mentoring and training opportunities. New Plant Operators receive initial training on the Operating Procedures and Safe Work Practices.  Once operations fundamentals are established, the new employees are mentored by a senior plant operator or the plant Operations Supervisor.  Process operating responsibilities are transferred to the new employee after observations indicate the new employee exhibits sufficient proficiency in the process operations. All operators  periodically receive refresher training on the operating procedures to ensure that their skills and knowledge are maintained at an acceptable level. This refresher training is conducted at least every 3 years. All of this training is documented for each operator, including the means used to verify that the operator understood the training. 





Contractors

The Dollarhide Gas Plant uses contractors to supplement its work force during periods of increased maintenance or construction activities. Because some contractors work on or near process equipment, the gas plant has procedures in place to ensure that contractors:



1.    Participate in Contractor / Visitor Orientation to receive an overview of the process and its hazards, and emergency action plan requirements  

2.    Perform their work in a safe manner

3.    Have appropriate knowledge and skills

4.    Aware of the hazards in their workplace

5.    Understand what they should do in the event of an emergency

6.    Understand and follow site safety rules

7.    Inform gas plant personnel of any hazards that they find during their work. 



Dollarhide Gas Plant evaluates contractor safety programs and performance during the selection of a contractor. Gas plant personnel periodically monitor contractor performance to ensure that contractors are fulfilling their safety and performance obligations. 



Pre-startup Safety Reviews (PSSR):

The Dollarhide Gas Plant conducts a PSSR for any new facility or facility m

odification that requires a change in the process safety information. The purpose of the PSSR is to ensure that safety features, procedures, personnel, and equipment are appropriately prepared for startup prior to placing the equipment into service.  This review provides a final check to make sure construction is in accordance with the design specifications and that all supporting systems are operationally ready. The PSSR review uses checklists to verify all aspects of readiness.  A PSSR involves verification of the construction and serves a quality assurance function by requiring verification that prevention requirements are properly implemented.



Mechanical Integrity:

The  Dollarhide  Gas  Plant has  well-established practices and  procedures to maintain  pressure vessels,  piping systems, pressure relief, vent systems, operating controls, pumps, compressors,  and  emergency shutdown  systems  in a safe operating  condition. The basic aspects of this include:

 

1.    Conducting training

2.    Following written procedures

3.    Performing inspections and tests

4.    Correcting identified deficiencies

5.      Applying quality assurance measures



These activities form a system that maintains the mechanical integrity of the process. Inspections and tests are performed to help ensure that equipment functions as intended and to verify that equipment is within acceptable limits (e.g., adequate wall thickness for pressure vessels). Application of various elements of Scout's Operating Management ensures mechanical integrity is maintained on existing and new installations.



Safe Work Practices:

The Dollarhide Gas Plant has long-standing safe work practices and procedures in place to ensure worker and process safety.  Through compliance with Scout Dollarhide established policy and procedures and adherence to appropriate OSHA regulations the safe work compliance standards of PSM / RMP are met. 



Management of Change:

The Management of Change (MOC) process is used to iden

tify, evaluate, and control hazards in the workplace that may be introduced because of change.  The process establishes the minimum procedures necessary to provide for the safety of personnel and facilities due to these changes or modifications.  The MOC process applies to all work done by Scout employees or contractors.  Changes to equipment or operations which are not replaced "in kind" require appropriate review and approval prior to implementation.  This review is necessary to ensure the safety of personnel and the integrity of the facilities.  The established procedure communicates changes or modifications to effected employees or contractors.



Incident Investigation:

The Dollarhide Gas Plant promptly investigates all incidents that resulted in, or reasonably could have resulted in, a fire/explosion, toxic gas release, major property damage, environmental loss, or personal injury. The goal of each investigation is to determine the facts and develop corrective actions to prevent a recurrence of the incident or a similar incident. The investigation team documents its findings, develops recommendations to prevent a recurrence, and forwards these results to gas plant management for resolution. Corrective actions taken in response to the investigation team's findings and recommendations are tracked until they are complete. The final resolution of each finding or recommendation is documented, and the investigation reports are retained for at least 5 years so that the reports can be reviewed during future PHAs and PHA revalidation. Also, incident investigation reports are shared with affected

personnel. 



Compliance Audits:

To help ensure that the accident prevention program is functioning properly, the Dollarhide Gas Plant periodically conducts an audit to determine whether the established policies, procedures and practices are implemented, followed and adequate. Compliance audits are conducted at least every 3 years. Personnel from other facilities who are kn

owledgeable in the audit process participate as audit team members. The audit team develops findings that are forwarded to gas plant management for resolution. Corrective actions taken in response to the audit team's findings are tracked until they are complete. The final resolution of each finding is documented, and the two most recent audit reports are retained.



CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS

Previously mentioned programs, policies and procedures outlines the primary emphasis of Scout procedural and administrative measures to prevent accidental hazardous releases at the Dollarhide Plant.



Site specific equipment and technology utilized for prevention of accidental releases of regulated substances and provide warning and protection to affected personnel in the facility include:

1. Centralized monitoring and control system with remote access capability.   

2. Critical Process Safety Valves that discharge to a closed flare to capture and incinerate episodic releases or atmospheric release as appropriate. 

3. Isolation Valves to isolate and control releases as appropriate (manual and automated)

4. Automated shutdown systems for critical process deviations.

5. Redundant equipment and instrumentation (e.g., uninterruptible power supply for process control system, backup).

6. Personal protective equipment (e.g., FR protective clothing, safety glasses, splash proof goggles, Nitril disposable gloves, self-contained breathing apparatus)

7. Personal H2S Monitors

8. Fixed H2S Monitors



FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

The Dollarhide Gas Plant has an excellent record (no incidents that resulted in onsite or offsite effects) of accident prevention over the past 5 years. However, if an incident did occur, we would investigate the incident very carefully to determine ways to prevent similar incidents from recurring.



EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM INFORMATION

The  Dollarhide  Gas  Plant maintains a written emergency action plan, which is in place to protect worker a

nd public safety as well as the environment. The plan consists of procedures for responding to a release of a regulated substance, including the possibility of a fire or explosion if a flammable substance is accidentally released. The action plan addresses proper first aid and medical treatment for exposures, evacuation plans and accounting for personnel after an evacuation, and notification of local emergency response agencies if a release occurs. Employees receive training in these procedures as necessary to perform their specific emergency response duties. The emergency action plan is updated when necessary based on modifications made to the gas plant process or a change in personnel responsibilities.



The overall emergency response program for the Dollarhide Gas Plant is coordinated with the local Emergency Agencies located in the adjacent communities. This coordination includes periodic updates to the local emergency response officials.  The Dollarhide Gas Plant has around-the-clock communications capability with appropriate officials and emergency response organizations. This provides a means of notifying the public of an incident, if necessary, as well as facilitating quick response to an incident. The Dollarhide Gas Plant conducts a table top or physical emergency drill on an Annual basis.



PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

The primary vehicle for the continued development of a comprehensive safety program at the Dollarhide Plant is the implementation of Socut saftey and PSM programs.  Under the direction of the these programs, where applicable new technology, equipment and practices will be utilized to eliminate, control or mitigate site specific risk exposures to affected personnel, the public and the environment. As an example, the Dollarhide Gas Plant has recently made changes to the process to reduce the inventory of flammable hydrocarbons by isolating from the process and decommissioning the off-spec NGL tanks, which contributes to reduce risk.
